buildings.name: AIDS Committee of Ottawa
buildings.description: The AIDS Committee of Ottawa (ACO) has served the HIV/AIDS community for 30 years, providing education and support services around HIV/AIDS. Built in 1961 and overlooking the Rideau Canal, the home of the ACO features a drop-in centre known as the Living Room - a place of comfort and care that pays tribute to the origins of the HIV/AIDS movement in Canada in the early 80s.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the AIDS Committee of Ottawa drop-in centre, known as the Living Room.

buildings.name: All Saints Anglican Church, Greely (ASG)
buildings.description: Built in 1889, on land donated by Richard Stanley, All Saints Greely was dedicated in honour of those saintly persons who have no special day in the year. This small church has 10 stained glass windows, 16 benches for a congregation of 75 parishioners in a 635 sq. ft. nave, an 80 sq. ft. altar & a 575 sq. ft. hall for events, facilities and storage. Weekly services are held Sunday at 9 a.m.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the small chapel featuring wodden benches and the pulpit.

buildings.name: allsaints Event Space
buildings.description: Once the site of Canada's only royal wedding, and the parish of many prominent Canadians, including The Right Honourable Sir Robert Borden, allsaints was recently purchased by a unique partnership of businesses and local residents. Together, they are working to lovingly restore this national historic building and renew it as a multi-purpose urban space. allsaints features stunning WWI memorial stained glass windows, beautifully repointed stone, and a rare nine-bell chime in the tower.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the red church door.

buildings.name: Bank of Canada
buildings.description: The Bank of Canada’s head office on Wellington Street combines classic and modern architecture. Doors Open visitors can tour the striking garden atrium designed by renowned Canadian architect Arthur Erickson as well as the art deco marble lobby from the 1930s. The Bank of Canada Museum will also offer interactive exhibitions for all ages. Visit bankofcanada.ca/doors-open for more information.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a glass multi-storey building.

buildings.name: Barry Padolsky Associates Inc. Architects, Mercury Court Building
buildings.description: Originally built in 1923 as Larocque’s Department Store, Mercury Court was renovated and expanded by Barry Padolsky Associates Inc. Architects from 1989 to 1993; it is now home to this architectural firm. Features include the “Flying Mercury” weathervane, which adorned the Sun Life Building at Bank and Sparks Streets until 1949.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the three-storey brick Mercury Court building and the "Flying Mercury"weathervane.

buildings.name: Beckta Dining & Wine Bar
buildings.description: Beckta is a landmark fine dining restaurant that relocated to the historic Grant House in November of 2014. The building has a heritage designation for both the interior and exterior, and was the home and workplace of Dr. James Grant, Canada's first Surgeon General. The building has also housed the University Club of Ottawa as well as Friday's Roast Beef House.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone three-storey historic Grant House.

buildings.name: Beechwood Cemetery
buildings.description:
Founded in 1873, Beechwood was designated a National Historic Site in 2001 because of its key role in Canadian heritage. It is a reflection of Canada’s identity as a multicultural and multi-faith society. Over 400 famous burials reside on the grounds including politicians, writers, and inventors. 
Tours are available as follows: 
• Mausoleum – Sat. & Sun., 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.
• National Memorial Centre and Hall of Colours – Sun. only, 10 a.m. to 12 p.m.
• Historical walking tours - Sat. & Sun. at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. (90 min. per tour - bilingual).
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone mausoleum and gardens.

buildings.name: Billings Estate Artefact Collection Storage
buildings.description: Explore behind the scenes of the Billings Estate National Historic Site artefact collection, listen to the stories these treasures tell, and learn how the City of Ottawa cares for historic artefacts. Experience pieces from the past first hand by investigating an object and seeing what secrets you can unlock!
buildings.imageDescription: Collage of artefacts including a rocking chair, clock, and table.

buildings.name: Billings Estate National Historic Site
buildings.description: Braddish Billings, the first settler of Gloucester Township, built Ottawa’s oldest wood-frame house, Billings Estate National Historic Site, from 1827-1829. Learn about the architectural details as you tour the home from basement to attic and learn about the evolution of the property. Explore the history of transportation in Ottawa from canoes to country roads in a new special exhibition, City in Motion.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of Ottawa's oldest wood-frame house. It is white with black shutters, features a second storey balcony, and  lush summer gardens.

buildings.name: Bridgehead Roastery
buildings.description: Bridgehead restored the beauty and character of this original structure, which was a carriage stable built in the 1920s, to use as the roastery that supplies fair trade and organic coffee to all 20 of their Ottawa locations. Main level accessible. Roastery open Mon. to Sun. 6:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.
buildings.imageDescription: A photo of a giant coffee roasting machine with coffee beans inside.

buildings.name: Britannia Yacht Club
buildings.address: 2777 Cassels St., North Side of Tennis Courts at the end of Cassels Street
buildings.description: Established in 1887, the newly renovated clubhouse boasts the beautiful Dragon Lounge where visitors can see a unique bar fashioned out of a dragon sailboat. Visitors will notice a large stone tower that is part of the original structure. Despite additions, the clubhouse still retains its historic appearance. It offers one of the best views of the Ottawa River that is enjoyed by our members year round.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view from the water of the club house, docks and stone retaining wall, and the original stone tower.

buildings.name: BYTOWN MUSEUM: Commissariat Building
buildings.description: Discover the secrets hidden within Ottawa’s oldest stone building, the Commissariat, home of the BYTOWN MUSEUM in this special behind-the-scene tour! Learn all about this spectacular heritage building from the foundation to the rafters, the vault, and stories of its former uses and inhabitants. One hundred and ninety-one years later, this building still has much to tell.
buildings.imageDescription: Ottawa's oldest stone building, built in 1827, nestled on the Rideau Canal.

buildings.name: Canada Aviation and Space Museum - Reserve Hangar
buildings.description: The Reserve Hangar is home to over 60 aircraft and unique artefacts. The visit is self-guided and takes approximately 45 minutes. Staff and volunteers will be stationed throughout the Reserve Hangar to offer interpretation. Please note that there is a maximum visitor capacity to the Reserve Hangar which may cause wait times to access the building.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a large storage hangar with large glass panels along the side and a triangular accent wall.

buildings.name: Canada Council Art Bank
buildings.description: The Canada Council Art Bank is home to over 17,000 contemporary Canadian artworks, including paintings, works on paper, sculpture and fibre works. The Art Bank offers Canadians unique public access to original art through its three programs – art rental, museum loans and outreach projects. Enjoy a behind-the-scenes tour of the Art Bank with art experts and view a thematic display of artworks related to transportation and the environment in the lead-up to the opening of Ottawa’s Light Rail Transit System (LRT).
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the Canada Council's art collection storage area featuring thousands of paintings.

buildings.name: Canadian Conservation Institute
buildings.address: 1030 Innes Rd. (corner of Innes & St. Laurent)
buildings.description: Discover the fascinating world of heritage conservation and conservation science! Learn how the Canadian Conservation Institute supports museums, archives, and historic sites of Canada in conserving our heritage collections so they can be accessed by current and future generations.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a fully secure, climate-controlled laboratory building.

buildings.name: Canadian Space Services
buildings.description: In 1960, NATO and the Canadian Department of National Defence built this satellite communications (SATCOM) station. Supporting a 68-ft. diameter metal space frame radar dome on its roof, it provides environmental protection for the 50-ft. diameter SATCOM antenna it houses. The antenna provided satellite communications between all NATO countries until 1999. It is now headquarters for the Canadian Space Services Ltd., CSS Wind Inc., and Rocky Mountain Equipment Ltd.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a building with a giant metal space frame radar dome on its roof.

buildings.name: Cancer research lab at The Ottawa Hospital
buildings.description: Discover fascinating cancer research with a behind-the-scenes tour of a research lab at The Ottawa Hospital Cancer Centre. Don a lab coat to explore the lab’s high-tech tools. For safety reasons, visitors must be 16 years or older. Forty-minute guided tours leave every hour from the Cancer Centre lobby. Space is limited, registration is required. Pre-register at http://www.ottawahospital.on.ca/en/about-us/doors-open-ottawa/.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the multi-storey glass Cancer research lab.

buildings.name: Carleton Masonic Lodge 465
buildings.description: The original lodge was built in 1904, but was destroyed by the great fire in Carp in 1920. The current building was originally the old Presbyterian Church located in Carp and was purchased to replace the lodge lost in the fire. Accentuated by original stained glass windows, it has been the Village of Carp’s Masonic Lodge since 1925. The lodge’s interior features beautiful oak furniture used by a military Masonic Lodge in France during WWI.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of what was once a small Presbyterian Church, featuring a lower level door, white siding, and a stained glass window directly above.

buildings.name: Carp Exhibit Hall
buildings.description: The red painted frame building with white trim remains a focal point in the Carp area to this day. One of the few remaining octagonal fairground buildings once so popular in Ontario, it continues to function as the main hall for the Carp Fair, and the popular Carp Farmers’ Market.
buildings.imageDescription: A red octagon-shaped barn-style building with white trim.

buildings.name: Centre de services Guigues
buildings.description: École Guigues played a leading role in the development of Franco-Ontarian identity and collective memory. Having served Franco-Ontarian youth as a centre of learning for more than a century, École Guigues is one of the best-known French-language schools in Francophone Ontario. With origins dating back to 1864, the school is located on Murray Street in Lowertown.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the three-storey red brick former school house.

buildings.name: Christ Church Bells Corners Chapel & Cemetery
buildings.description: The Bells Corners Union Cemetery dates from 1853 and is located on land given by the founder of the community, Hugh Bell. In 1876, the Anglican congregation built their church, which is still in use every Sunday. Visitors will hear stories behind the stained glass, the wood paneling and a variety of personages in the cemetery as they complete a guided tour and enjoy a Historical Strawberry Tea.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the front of the small chapel featuring carved wooden walls and stained glass windows above the alter.

buildings.name: Christ Church Cathedral Ottawa
buildings.description: The original parish of Christ Church Bytown was established in 1832 on unceded Algonquin territory. In 1870, architect King Arnoldi was commissioned to build a bigger church in the English Gothic style to harmonize with the new Parliament buildings. Named the Cathedral of the Diocese in 1897, it continues to nurture faith in creative and traditional ways, and is often used for ecumenical, interfaith and state events.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a Middle Pointed style of English Gothic stone church and bell tower, built in 1870.

buildings.name: Church of St. Bartholomew
buildings.description: Founded in 1867, the heritage designated church was designed by architect Thomas Seaton Scott on land donated by the estate of Thomas MacKay, founder of New Edinburgh. Discover artefacts about the local community, Canada’s Governor Generals and the Governor General’s Foot Guards. Highlights include the Memorial East Window by Wilhelmina Geddes (1919) and the new Létourneau organ (2013).
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone church and its walkway lined with flowers.

buildings.name: City of Ottawa Archives, Rideau Branch
buildings.description: Rideau Archives is in the former Township Hall of North Gower, built in 1876; a one-storey, brick-faced example of a modest hall with fine proportions, careful detailing and a cupola. The archival collection highlights material from the southern rural part of Ottawa. The current exhibit commemorates the service and sacrifice of Rideau’s citizens in the Great War, 1914 to 1918.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a one-storey brick-faced modest town hall with careful detailing and a cupola, built in 1876.

buildings.name: City of Ottawa Spay/Neuter Clinic
buildings.description: For almost 40 years, the City of Ottawa Spay/Neuter Clinic has been helping cats and dogs live better lives through sterilization. During Doors Open Ottawa, the City invites you to take a tour to learn how the Clinic provides affordable service without sacrificing quality of care.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the kennel area that houses animals before getting spayed or neutered.

buildings.name: CKCU Radio University Centre
buildings.address: 1125 Colonel By Dr., Room 517, University Centre
buildings.description: CKCU is Canada’s oldest campus community radio station.  It broadcasts live 24 hours a day to a 100 km radius on FM 93.1 and around the world on ckcufm.com. Enjoy station tours with the hosts to learn about the world of radio. Parking lot 2 is the closest parking lot and will cost around $4. Buses and the O-Train stop on campus. It is also accessible via city bike paths.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the radio centre corridor and a CKCU radio sign.

buildings.name: Connaught Building
buildings.description: Built in Modified Norman style and designed by David Ewart, Connaught opened in 1915 and was named after the Duke of Connaught, third son of Queen Victoria and Governor General of Canada 1911to 1916. Designated as a Classified federal heritage building, primarily for its architectural significance, the structure is considered to be the “Crown Jewel” of the Canada Revenue Agency. Access is limited to the Mackenzie lobby area and the 8th floor executive boardroom.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a Modified Norman style stone building built in 1915.

buildings.name: Cumberland Heritage Village Museum
buildings.description: Cumberland Heritage Village Museum offers historic and reproduction buildings clustered on picturesque grounds depicting rural life in the 1920s and 1930s. Tour an operational sawmill and blacksmith shop, a one-room school house, a 1927 Imperial Gas garage, a 1904 church and family homes. Explore the history of transportation in Ottawa from Railways to Highways in our new exhibition, City in Motion.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the former Vars train station and a red caboose.

buildings.name: Dickinson House
buildings.description: Built in 1867, the year of Canada’s Confederation, by M.K. Dickinson, founder of the village of Manotick, this 150-year-old house was the residence, from 1870 to 1972 of the Dickinson, Spratt and Watson families, owner/operators of the grist mill across the square. The house was visited by Sir John A. Macdonald during the 1887 General Election.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a yellow, two-storey home with green shutters built in 1870.

buildings.name: Diefenbunker: Canada's Cold War Museum
buildings.description: The Diefenbunker: Canada’s Cold War Museum is a four-storey Cold War bunker built to protect the government from a nuclear attack on Ottawa. Once top-secret, this underground facility is now open year-round. Free tours in French and English by reservation only. Please visit www.diefenbunker.ca in early May to reserve your space.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of a 1960s retro boardroom with mounted televisions, a projector, and clocks featuring the different time zones on the wall.

buildings.name: Discovery Centre, Carleton University
buildings.address: 1125 Colonel By Drive, MacOdrum Library, 4th Floor
buildings.description: The Discovery Centre is a 9,500 square foot collaborative workspace for undergraduate research. This dynamic learning environment is outfitted with ergonomic, accessible and stylish furniture as well as state-of-the-art technology. Complete with three Library Laboratories (Gaming, Learning, Multi-Media) available for student and faculty use, this multi-purpose space can suit a wide range of needs.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of a gaming lab, including flat screen TVs and equipment.

buildings.name: Dominican University College
buildings.description: The stone structure of Dominican University College displays the vaulted ceilings typical of neo-Gothic design. An interior courtyard visible through large windows opens onto elegant gardens. The highly reputed library is distinguished by its stained glass and the Wilson Room, dedicated to antiquated books dating back to the 15th century.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a four-storey stone building with a flat roof and an adjoining bell tower.

buildings.name: Dormition of the Virgin Mary Greek Orthodox Church
buildings.description: Built in 1975, and designed by architect Konstantinos Zourdoumis. A fine example of Neo-Byzantine style with its domed structure. Highlights include hand-painted Byzantine icons on the domed ceiling and walls, the hand-carved wood Iconostasion wall of icons in front of the Altar, and mosaic tiles. Photography permitted. Services at 10 a.m. on Sunday.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the hand-carved wood Iconostasion wall of icons in front of the Altar, and mosaic tiles.

buildings.name: Elections Canada Distribution Centre
buildings.description: Completed in 1968, the building at 440 Coventry was designed as a headquarters for both the Canadian Exhibition Commission and Canada’s Chief Electoral Officer. Today, it is still home to the Elections Canada Distribution Centre, where almost all of the materials used across the country in a federal election or by-election are received, stored, packed and shipped.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of Elections Canada voting material ready for distribution.

buildings.name: Embassy of Algeria, Fleck-Paterson House
buildings.description: The house was built in 1901 by J.R. Booth for his daughter, Gertrude Fleck. The house remained Mrs. Fleck’s private residence until her death in 1940. It was then purchased by Senator Norman Paterson, who lived in it until his death in 1983. The house was bought by the Algerian Embassy in 2002 and is now used as a chancery.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a terracotta-style mansion featuring turrets and fancy brickwork.

buildings.name: Embassy of Hungary
buildings.description: The Embassy of Hungary is located in the historic Birkett Castle which was built in 1896 by Mr. Thomas Birkett, who served as Mayor of Ottawa. The building was built in the Baronial Gothic style, features towers, a crenellated roofline, wood panelling, a variety of fine ornaments, and stained glass windows. It was acquired by the Government of Hungary in 1994.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of a red brick two-storey mansion that resembles a castle with a corner turret.

buildings.name: Embassy of the Czech Republic
buildings.description: The construction of the building dates back to 1879, and is typical of late Victorian vernacular architecture in North America. In 1913 it was enlarged to twice its size. The Liberal Federation took it over in 1957 as their headquarters. The University Club bought the property in 1970. Starting 2000, this building became the Czech Embassy. In 2006, portions of the Embassy were carefully renovated. Guided tours on ground floor only.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a brick, three-storey home typical of late Victorian vernacular architecture.

buildings.name: Embassy of the Republic of Croatia
buildings.description: Known as Toller House, it was built in the Domestic Gothic Revival style by Henry Horsey and J. Sheard, architects in 1875. The building was home to many dignitaries including Frederic Toller, Auditor General of the Dominion’s Currency in the 1880s. In 1999, it opened as the Embassy of Croatia after an award-winning restoration. Guided tours on ground level only.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a brick, two-storey home built in Domestic Gothic Revival style in 1875.

buildings.name: Enriched Bread Artists
buildings.description: Enriched Bread Artists is celebrating its 26th year in the former Standard Bread Company building. Opened in 1924, the building’s plaque with the Latin proverb: Audaces Fortuna Juvat meaning Fortune Favours the Bold, can still be seen near the entrance. It is now home to artists’ studios boldly continuing to sustain Ottawa.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a multi-storey building built in 1924.

buildings.name: Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul
buildings.description: In 1887, A. Harvey designed a new limestone Gothic Revival church to replace a modest frame church built in 1875. The cornerstone was laid on May 21, 1888. Renowned architect W.E. Noffke oversaw renovations in 1948. Further renovations were completed in 2015. In 2017, the church celebrated the 500th year anniversary of the Reformation.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone Gothic Revival church with two red doors built in 1887.

buildings.name: Faculty of Medicine, University of Ottawa (Roger Guindon Hall - RGN)
buildings.description: Founded in 1945, uOttawa’s Faculty of Medicine is a leader in medical education and research. With 1,000 + rooms including labs and state-of-the-art facilities, RGN is home to physicians-in-training, aspiring scientists, and some of Canada’s top researchers. Hear from uOBMRI and CI3 researchers about their fascinating discoveries in the treatment of brain-related illness and infections and inflammatory diseases. Guided tours (En). Min age : 6yrs.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the large University of Ottawa medical building.

buildings.name: Fairfields Heritage House
buildings.description: Fairfields Heritage House, a 19th century Gothic revival farmhouse, was the first heritage property designated by the former municipality of Nepean. Five generations of the Bell family lived in the home, and it was from here that they became successful in their farming, law and political endeavours. Photography permitted. Guided tours available.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a  stone19th century gothic revival farmhouse with white trim.

buildings.name: First Baptist Church Ottawa
buildings.description:
(Sunday church service from 10:30 to 11:45 a.m.)
Designed by James Mather in the Gothic Revival style, the cornerstone of the church was laid in July 26, 1877 by then PM Alexander Mackenzie who was a regular worshipper. The church was designated a civic historic building in 1985. The sanctuary features interesting stained glass windows - one with an Ottawa Valley theme. Open for Sunday worship June 3.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone Gothic Revival style church with a modern skyscraper in the background.

buildings.name: First Church of Christ, Scientist
buildings.description: Constructed in 1913, Ottawa architect J.P. MacLaren designed the church in Classic Italian style. Using Ohio sandstone, Corinthian columns, pediments, a recessed doorway and a temple plan, it features a spacious auditorium and three-manual Casavant pipe organ. No photos during 10 a.m. Sunday service. Organ demonstrations 12:45 PM, 2:00 PM both days.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a Classic Italian style church made of sandstone built in 1913.

buildings.name: Flora Hall Brewing
buildings.description: Built in the 1920s as an electrical garage, then an auto garage and now, after being empty for 10 years or more, rescued and renovated from top to bottom as a craft brewery. The original stucco facade, garage door and iconic arch have all been maintained, and the interior is respectful of the building’s industrial past. Come in and see how great beer is made!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior evening view of the Flora Hall Brewing building, a former 1960s garage.

buildings.name: French Embassy in Canada
buildings.description: A prime example of 1930s Art Deco, built primarily of materials from Quebec and France (Bourgogne and St. Quentin). Architectural highlights inside include a replica of the Vimy Memorial, tapestries, bronze doors, the Birch Room, decorations by André Bizette-Lindet, a mural by Alfred Courmes, and historical wall engravings. Colourized photo exhibition “The Great War in Colour”. No strollers, backpacks, or metal objects. Photography limited. Pre-registration required at https://ca.ambafrance.org between May 15 and June 2, 2018. A limited number of passes are available on a first come, first serve basis (last admission at 5 pm – closed from noon to 1 p.m.). No food or drink.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the 1930s art deco French Embassy building and surrounding property.

buildings.name: Fung Loy Kok Institute of Taoism Ottawa Branch Centre
buildings.description: The Ottawa Branch Centre of the Fung Loy Kok Institute of Taoism is home to a shrine dedicated to Guanyin, the bodhisattva of compassion, as well as three Star Deities. Blessed lanterns and other elements of The Three Teachings School of Taoism decorate the space. The main practice hall is where Taoist arts, such as Taoist Tai Chi®, Lok Hup Ba Fa, chanting and meditation, are practiced.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a one-storey white stucco building.

buildings.name: Geomagnetic Laboratory of Natural Resources Canada
buildings.description: Tour the Geomagnetic Laboratory of Natural Resources Canada on Anderson Road. It’s the 50th anniversary! Visit the Canadian Space Weather Forecast Centre and learn about space weather forecasting. Discover geomagnetism and the Canadian Magnetic Observatory Network. Check out earthquake monitoring in Canada, watch earthquake-recording instruments in action, and see live waveforms from our earthquake monitoring stations across Canada.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the one-storey N.R. Can Geogmagnetic Lab, surrounded by forest.

buildings.name: Global Centre for Pluralism
buildings.description: The Global Centre for Pluralism, formerly the Public Archives 1905 to 1967 and Canadian War Museum 1967to 2005, has been transformed by a $35 million investment from His Highness the Aga Khan into the home of an organization that seeks to deepen understanding about the sources of inclusion and exclusion around the world through analysis, education and dialogue.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a fully restored, L-shaped, three-storey early 1900s stone building

buildings.name: Gloucester Artefact Collection Storage - Leitrim Complex
buildings.description: Explore behind the scenes of the Gloucester artefact collection, listen to the stories these treasures tell, and learn how the City of Ottawa cares for historic artefacts. Experience pieces from the past firsthand by investigating an object and seeing what secrets you can unlock!
buildings.imageDescription: Picture of several artefacts from the Gloucester collection, including a banjo, a pitcher, and a toy airplane.

buildings.name: Gloucester Historical Society
buildings.address: 4550B Bank St., Lower Level off of Leitrim Road
buildings.description: Built in 1962, the Gloucester Historical Society resides in the former Gloucester Township Hall. Volunteers will address questions regarding the history of Gloucester, and offer tours of the Gloucester museum artefacts located in the same building. Historic St. James Anglican Church will also be open next door. Parking is available off Leitrim Road next to the Fire Hall.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the former Gloucester Township Hall, built in 1962. The building is made of stone, and surrounded by green shrubs.

buildings.name: Goulbourn Museum
buildings.description: Built in 1872, the building currently known as the Goulbourn Museum used to be the old Town Hall. It was originally home to council meetings, parties, and dances. The adjacent History Centre building was built in 1961, and was the former Clerks building. Now it is used as office space, and stores the Museum’s collection of over 9,000 artefacts.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone, one-storey building built in 1872.

buildings.name: Heritage Building and Ottawa City Hall
buildings.address: 110 Laurier Ave. West, Elgin St. Entrance
buildings.description: Designed by R.W. Strickland and Kivas Tully, the Heritage Building features high Victorian design. Formerly the teachers’ college, it became Ottawa City Hall after municipal amalgamation. Saturday only: Coffee in the Mayor’s Office from 10 a.m. to noon.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone, high-Victorian style building and a large tree.

buildings.name: HI-Ottawa Jail Hostel
buildings.description: Located in the former Carleton County Gaol, the HI-Ottawa Jail Hostel is steeped in history. Opened as a hostel since 1973, this building has become an international hub for backpackers and travelers in the Nation’s Capital for 45 years.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone multi-storey former Carleton gaol, featuring its multiple chimneys lining the roof and ivy-covered stone wall that once created a courtyard.

buildings.name: High Commission of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago
buildings.description: Built in 1914 by Bell Canada as a telephone exchange, this building currently houses the High Commission of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The exterior features gray Ohio sandstone trim and dark red pressed brick. The interior has been redesigned to include offices, a reception area and colorful exhibits that showcase Trinidad and Tobago.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view featuring gray Ohio sandstone trim and dark red pressed brick, built in 1914.

buildings.name: Hindu Temple of Ottawa-Carleton Inc.
buildings.description: Designed according to specific religious architectural traditions, the temple stands as a monument to Hindu heritage in Ottawa. It is home to many deities and shrines made of granite, marble and bronze, all sculpted in India. There is an assembly hall and a library. Please remove shoes upon entering. No photography of shrines or deities.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view designed according to specific religious architectural traditions of the Hindu faith.

buildings.name: Hydro Ottawa’s new Hydroelectric facility at Chaudière Falls
buildings.description: For the first time in over 100 years, Chaudière Falls is open to the public! The expanded Chaudière Falls generating station exemplifies responsible hydroelectric generation with minimal to zero impact on the visual, natural and aquatic environments. Get an insider-look at the state-of-the-art facility as well as heritage elements celebrating Canada’s First Nations and Ottawa’s industrialist past. Parking will be available on Victoria Island. Closed-toe shoes are required (no high heels).
buildings.imageDescription: View of the Chuadière Falls with the new Hydro Ottawa facility behind it.

buildings.name: Innovation Centre at Bayview Yards
buildings.description: The former City of Ottawa Workshops Building #4 at Bayview Yards is a heritage designated, circa 1941, industrial building west of downtown Ottawa. The retrofit and upgrade of the building is an adaptive reuse with elements of preservation and restoration, best described as an unadorned example of a Modern Style industrial building designed to convey innovation, dynamics, industry and discovery.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of an imposing red metal staircase nestled in the middle of a shared community office space in what was once a former garage.

buildings.name: Jami Omar Mosque
buildings.description: Welcome to Jami Omar Mosque. Originally established in 1992, this mosque is one of the largest in Canada. Enjoy interactive guided tours and a day full of interesting activities for the whole family. Free gifts for everyone, free tasty refreshments, poster exhibition, cultural display, and much more!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a 50,000 square foot prayer, physical, social and intellectual facility for the Muslim community.

buildings.name: Jean-Léon Library, Saint Paul University
buildings.description: The Jean-Léon Allie Library at Saint Paul University was created in 1937. It boasts the largest theological collection in the country, with over half a million items spread over seven floors. The collection boasts many treasures, including over 10,000 rare books, most of them printed before 1800. The rare books collection includes 12 incunabula; the oldest dates from 1475.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the front entrance of the university and the black and organce sign in front.

buildings.name: Joyful Land Kadampa Buddhist Centre
buildings.description: Established in 1996 under the direction of Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche, Joyful Land is the focal point for the Ottawa community of the modern tradition of Mahayana Buddhism called New Kadampa Tradition. Visit the heart of the building, a beautiful shrine where marvelous Buddha statues can be admired, and learn about meditation programs helping people to develop inner peace and good hearts. The bookshop offers an extensive selection of books, ritual implements and artwork.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the building, including the Joyful Land building sign and newly renovated porch.

buildings.name: Knox Presbyterian Church Ottawa
buildings.description: Knox was completed in 1933, and combines elements of English Gothic and Norman Church architecture. The Sanctuary is simple and unadorned yet beautiful, accented by soaring columns and different marble and stone materials, and two stained glass windows.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo featuring elements of English Gothic and Norman Church architecture, built in 1933.

buildings.name: La Nouvelle Scène Gilles Desjardins (LNSGD)
buildings.description: LNSGD, also known as the Centre de théâtre francophone d’Ottawa, is home to four resident theatre companies. This performing arts production and dissemination facility offers two performance studios that can accommodate 173 and 100 spectators, respectively. LNSGD also features a rehearsal studio, a courtyard and a bistro. The latter can accommodate over 200 people for special events.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the glass paneled theatre backlit with yellow, green, and red colours.

buildings.name: Laurentian Leadership Centre/J.R. Booth Mansion
buildings.description: A Queen Anne Revival mansion built in 1909 for John R. Booth, Ottawa’s wealthiest lumber baron. Architect John W.H. Watts designed this three-storey red brick building with interior hand-carved woodwork, stenciled ceiling, tapestry wallpaper and original light fixtures. Previously owned by the Laurentian Club, it’s now the Laurentian Leadership Centre of Trinity Western University.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of a red brick mansion with a white two-storey bay window and detailed carvings above the front entrance.

buildings.name: Laurier House National Historic Site
buildings.description: Laurier House commemorates two of Canada’s most notable prime ministers, Sir Wilfrid Laurier and the Rt. Hon. William Lyon Mackenzie King. For over fifty years, from 1897 to 1948, the house occupied a central position in the political life of Canada, as the place of residence of Laurier and, after his death, of Mackenzie King.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the beige coloured historic home with green awnings and roof, and a corner turret.

buildings.name: Lester B. Pearson Building; Global Affairs Canada
buildings.description: Opened in 1973, the Lester B. Pearson Building was designed as a modernist take on the Sphinx of ancient Egypt. Come visit exhibits on our missions and embassies abroad. For more information on our activities, visit Global Affairs Canada website, or follow us on Twitter @CanadaFP.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a large, multi-tiered brown building, a modernist take on the Sphinx of ancient Egypt, built in 1973.

buildings.name: Library and Archives Canada
buildings.description: Library and Archives Canada (1963 to 1967). The building consists of two four-storey wings and a central nine-storey tower. The lower floors, comprised of glass, form part of the boundary of a raised courtyard that leads to Wellington Street. The collections are housed in the central tower, which is studded with small square windows.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a building consisting of two four-story wings and a central nine-story tower.

buildings.name: Lisgar Collegiate Institute
buildings.description: The oldest school in the Ottawa Carleton District School Board, Lisgar Collegiate Institute, named after Canada’s second Governor General, was designed by W.T. Thomas and W. Chesterton as a Gothic Revival limestone structure in 1874. It features pointed arches, buttresses, decorative quoins, crenellated towers and oriel windows.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the limestone structure built in 1874 featuring pointed arches, buttresses, decorative quoins, crenellated towers and oriel windows.

buildings.name: Maplelawn Historic Garden
buildings.description: In the 19th century there were many fine houses in Ontario, but few were graced with walled gardens, and fewer still have survived. The walled garden at Maplelawn is a rare example and is also exceptionally well preserved. About 125 species of plants, most of them perennials, are still thriving there. In 2018, the Friends of Maplelawn Garden are celebrating their 25th year as stewards of this National Historic Site in caring for this perennial garden.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a 19th century historic garden and Thomson Hall in the background.

buildings.name: Masjid Bilal
buildings.description: Welcome to Masjid Bilal, a warm welcoming religious establishment with unique architectural design. Bilal Masjid is a good example of modern Islamic architecture, with a prominent minaret, dome and a stunningly beautiful prayer hall. We offer interactive and friendly guided tours, free snacks and poster exhibition.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a modern mosque featuring expansive arched windows, reminiscent of those found in Spain.

buildings.name: McMillan
buildings.description: The history of 541 Sussex is rich. It has housed the MacArthur British Hotel, military barracks rented by Sir John A. Macdonald, Clarendon House (hotel), The Department of Technical Survey, Natural History Museum, The Canadian Academy of Arts (which later became the National Gallery of Canada), The Canadian Geological Survey, a hospital during typhoid fever, and now McMillan Agency (as of 1998). ‘Escape’ the 2018 building tour at McMillan by problem-solving three challenges that will test your memory, and if successful, your group will win a nifty prize!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a three-storey stone building which was once used as military barracks by Sir John A Macdonald.

buildings.name: Mill Street Brewpub - Thompson Perkins Building
buildings.description: Mill Street Brewpub Ottawa opened in January 2012 within the historic Thompson-Perkins & Bronson Pulp Mill. Built in 1842, the limestone building is Ottawa’s oldest surviving mill that was once an integral part of one of the world’s largest lumbering operations. Today, the beautifully restored site offers unique views of the Capital and access to the Ottawa River. Enjoy guided tours of the brewery and grounds.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo at dusk of the two-storey stone mill with a darkening red sky.

buildings.name: Mosque of Mercy
buildings.description: Visit the Mosque of Mercy, one of the largest and most beautiful mosques in the City of Ottawa. Fully opened in May 2016, the mosque offers guided tours of the community hall, prayer area, library and more. Light refreshments will be served.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of a large rectangular beige coloured building and an apartment building in the background.

buildings.name: Mulligan Building: Parks Canada Conservation Laboratories
buildings.description: Parks Canada is proud to be recognized internationally for its conservation leadership and the steward of Canada’s natural and heritage treasures found in every province and territory. Enjoy a sneak peek at how valuable cultural treasures are cared for and preserved by conservators and conservation scientists in the laboratories.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of the grey and green coloured two-storey Parks Canada Conservation Labratories building.

buildings.name: National Gallery of Canada
buildings.description: (Open for regular hours on Sat. June 2 – admission rates apply). See Canada’s visual arts treasures within the lively Ottawa ByWard Market. Discover our completely reinvented Canadian and Indigenous Galleries and the country’s finest collection of European art. During any visit you can take in world-class special exhibitions and engaging activities for all ages.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a 569,000 square foot award-winning architectural gem, featuring soaring windows of the Great Hall framed by trees and greenery.

buildings.name: National Research Council Canada (NRC) - Temple of Science
buildings.description: The construction and care lavished on the fittings of sculptured bronze and Italian travertine demonstrate that the building was not only intended to be a laboratory facility, but also a work of art. This heritage building will offer visitors a chance to take the architecture, but also a series of special science and technology exhibits.
buildings.imageDescription: Aerial view of a laboratory facility featuring sculptured bronze and Italian travertine.

buildings.name: Nepean Museum
buildings.description: Nepean Museum resides in the original Nepean Library building and celebrates the history of the local community. Discover the history of Nepean’s landmark buildings by participating in a hands-on workshop activity, learn about Ottawa’s streetcar system in the summer exhibition, City in Motion, let your inner child loose at the ‘Play’ exhibit, and view historic objects during a tour of the collection storage space.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the exhibit 'Play' featuring interactive toys and displays.

buildings.name: Nepean Sailing Club
buildings.description: Established in 1979, the Nepean Sailing Club is a family-oriented, volunteer based organization dedicated to promoting and encouraging active participation by its members and the general public in the sport of sailing and recreational boating. Griffiths Rankin Cook Architects won an architectural award in 1990 for the design of the main clubhouse.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the main clubhouse which won an architectural award.

buildings.name: OC Transpo Bus and Train Simulator Training Facility
buildings.description: The Simulator Training Facility at 925 Belfast Road was recently completed in 2017 and offers electric, rail and bus operators simulated scenarios as part of their training. You will have the opportunity to see operators run actual simulations, learn about the technology, ask questions, see buses and experience how transit is evolving.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of a Light Rail cabin car with multiple passenger seats looking towards the main conductor. A simulation is playing on a screen.

buildings.name: OC Transpo Walkley Yard Maintenance Facility, O-Train Trillium Line
buildings.description: Walkley Yard was built by the NCC in 1955 so CN Rail freight trains could vacate the lands needed to build the Queensway. In 1967, CP Rail moved to the yard from Lebreton Flats. The City of Ottawa has leased the facility from CP since 2001 allowing Bombardier to handle the indoor maintenance of the O-Train Trillium Line’s trains. Come enjoy a guided tour of the facility!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of multiple red O-Trains stationed on the tracks at the maintenance yard.

buildings.name: Osgoode Township Museum
buildings.description: Discover what life was like in 19th century rural Ottawa at the Osgoode Township Museum. Visit the Agriculture Barn, home to an impressive collection of early farming tools and equipment important to the farming history of the Ottawa Valley. Also, don’t forget to explore the 1890’s Heritage School Garden and Orchard.  Learn about school gardens and sample many types of heirloom produce.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of the red brick museum in the background and old farming equipment in the foreground.

buildings.name: Ottawa Art Gallery
buildings.description: Ottawa Art Gallery spans five floors, with more than 55,000 sq ft. It features a dedicated gallery for the Firestone Collection of Canadian Art, a gallery for OAG’s Permanent Collection, two outdoor rooftop terraces, a large multi-purpose room with retractable seating for 250, and the OAG hands-on Studio for school and community programs. For Doors Open, take a sneak peek of the Pink Art Storage Vaults.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of modern white stairs set against a grey brick wall.

buildings.name: Ottawa Birth and Wellness Centre
buildings.description: The Ottawa Birth and Wellness Centre is a midwife-led, community-based birthing centre. From the outside, it looks like a regular office building (the OBWC is housed in the Canon building), but inside, the OBWC has been designed to be a warm, comfortable space for families to welcome their new babies into the world. Three birth rooms, education spaces, and storage spaces fill the 13,000+ sq foot space.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of a birthing room, featuring a hot tub, couches, and a fireplace.

buildings.name: Ottawa Chinese Bible Church
buildings.description: The Ottawa Chinese Bible Church recently renovated the former Wesley United Church building which served the Old Ottawa East community for over 60 years. The renovation combines the charm of the original building with modern accessible design. Architect Latimer Hu will be present during the day to answer questions about his work.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the renovated main entrance and new addition of an A-frame, brown-brick church.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 36
buildings.description: The City of Ottawa opened two new fire stations in February 2018 to better meet the fire and emergency protection needs in Pineview and Cumberland. Key facts - Each station is equipped with a pumper truck and 16 personnel. Construction of both buildings began in April 2017. The new facilities were designed by Hobin Architecture Inc. and built by Morley Hoppner Limited.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the new modern fire station, featuring the large garage doors and front entrance to the building.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 47
buildings.description: Ottawa Fire Services welcomes the public to tour a fire station within their community. Visitors will also be offered fire truck tours and a meet and greet with firefighters. Minimal parking available on site.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of the recently built Fire Station 47 and its three truck bays.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 55
buildings.description: The City of Ottawa opened two new fire stations in February 2018 to better meet the fire and emergency protection needs in Pineview and Cumberland. Key facts - Each station is equipped with a pumper truck and 16 personnel. Construction of both buildings began in April 2017. The new facilities were designed by Hobin Architecture Inc. and built by Morley Hoppner Limited.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the new modern fire station, featuring the large garage doors and front entrance to the building.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 64
buildings.description: Here is an opportunity for the public to tour the rural fire halls in their communities. Emphasis will be on public education and fire safety. Demonstrations, fire truck tours, meet and greet with firefighters.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a rural red-brick City of Ottawa Fire Station, featuring three fire trucks.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 81
buildings.description: Here is an opportunity for the public to tour the rural fire halls in their communities. Emphasis will be on public education and fire safety. Demonstrations, fire truck tours, meet and greet with firefighters.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a rural red-brick City of Ottawa Fire Station, featuring three fire trucks.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 84
buildings.description: Here is an opportunity for the public to tour the rural fire halls in their communities. Emphasis will be on public education and fire safety. Demonstrations, fire truck tours, meet and greet with firefighters.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a rural red-brick City of Ottawa Fire Station, featuring three fire trucks.

buildings.name: Ottawa Fire Station 93
buildings.description: Here is an opportunity for the public to tour the rural fire halls in their communities. Emphasis will be on public education and fire safety. Demonstrations, fire truck tours, meet and greet with firefighters.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a rural red-brick City of Ottawa Fire Station, featuring three fire trucks.

buildings.name: Ottawa Integrative Cancer Centre
buildings.description: The OICC is the first integrative cancer care and research centre in Eastern Canada. The OICC provides complementary cancer care, alongside conventional treatments, to improve quality of life for those living with cancer. The building was the first home for CJOH TV in 1961.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the former CJOH building, a brown brick rectangular structure built in 1961.

buildings.name: Ottawa Main Mosque
buildings.description: With a very distinct architectural design, the Ottawa Main Mosque is hard to miss while driving along Scott Street with its raised minaret and central dome. It can hold up to 700 people. Its design includes a two-storey prayer hall, library and basement used for meetings, childcare and social events.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a building with distinct architectural design, including a raised minaret and central dome.

buildings.name: Ottawa Masonic Centre/Tunis Shriners Temple
buildings.description: Built in 1975, the Ottawa Masonic Centre replaced the old Masonic Temple formerly on Metcalfe Street. Home to a number of fraternal organizations including 12 Masonic Lodges, Royal Arch Chapter, Scottish Rite Valley, Eastern Star Chapters (ladies groups), Rainbow Chapter (girls group), DeMolay Chapter (boys group) and a Shriners Temple. The building is filled with mystique and symbolism.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the main Masonic meeting room.

buildings.name: Ottawa New Edinburgh Club (ONEC)
buildings.address: 501 Sir George-Étienne Cartier Pkwy (formerly Rockcliffe Pkwy)
buildings.description: ONEC is a community-based rowing, sailing and tennis club. The boathouse, built between 1914 and 1923 in a style typical of its era, is a recognized federal heritage building. Visitors can access a ballroom and upper deck with grand views of the Ottawa River, and a display of photos, trophies and other memorabilia from the club’s colourful past.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the boathouse, built between 1914 and 1923, now recognized as a federal heritage building.

buildings.name: Ottawa Paramedic Service Headquarters
buildings.description: Opened in 2005, the 100,000 square-foot Ottawa Paramedic Service Headquarters is a state-of-the-art facility that houses all paramedic operations (except for medical dispatching), a vehicle depot and administrative area for the service. The building is the first in Ottawa to be certified as Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED).
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the 100,000 square foot state-of-the-art paramedic facility.

buildings.name: Ottawa Peace Latvian Evangelical Lutheran Church
buildings.description: Built in the early 20th century by architect W.C. Beattie, the church has been home to the Ottawa Peace Latvian congregation since September 30, 1982, while the lower level serves as a Latvian Community Centre. To mark Latvia’s Centenary in 2018, the congregation invites the public to share the rich and unique Latvian culture through traditional art, food, music, and dance. On Sunday, at 11 a.m., there will be a bilingual (Latvian/English) church service.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior front view of the early 20th century red brick church. The church has a flat roof featuring a small stone peak above the front entrance.

buildings.name: Ottawa Police Service Professional Development Centre
buildings.description: The Ottawa Police Professional Development Centre exists within the Algonquin College Police and Public Safety Institute. Police training goes on all year long, including academic courses, defensive tactics/scenarios and firearms training. New recruits, experienced officers and civilian members all enjoy training in this facility.
buildings.imageDescription: Photo of Ottawa Police Constable Cam Downie and his canine partner Eric.

buildings.name: Ottawa Rowing Club
buildings.description: The Ottawa Rowing Club, established in 1867 and home to almost 1,000 members, is Canada’s oldest and second largest rowing club in Canada. Our site on the Ottawa River features the original boathouse containing displays of ORC rowing history, and a larger boathouse containing a fleet of rowing shells. Learn about rowing and its history in Ottawa!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of Canada's oldest rowing club boathouse. The white siding is accented by the blue dormers and red roof.

buildings.name: Ottawa Tennis and Lawn Bowling Clubhouse
buildings.description: The Ottawa Tennis and Lawn Bowling is one of Canada’s largest and oldest tennis clubs. Celebrating its 137th year, the OTLBC has been in its current location for almost 100 years. Located on 5 acres on the Rideau River, the OTLBC has 18 clay tennis courts, 12 beach volleyball courts, an outdoor pool and a new, local restaurant. We invite you to explore our serene setting and historic clubhouse.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the two-storey, 130-year-old clubhouse featuring a wraparound terrace.

buildings.name: Ottawa Valley Wild Bird Care Centre
buildings.description: Built in 1992, the Wild Bird Care Centre is set within Ottawa’s greenbelt, surrounded by NCC trails. It has become a favourite place for nature enthusiasts and animal lovers alike. Operating solely on donations, this registered charity cares for ill, injured and orphaned wild birds found within the community and releases them back into the wild.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a wood, one-storey building located in a forested area.

buildings.name: Parkdale Food Centre
buildings.description: The Parkdale Food Centre operates as the Hintonburg-Mechanicsville community food bank, and has been serving those in need for the past 25+ years. The food bank will offer tours of the facility to show how a food bank works and how it supports those less fortunate in the community.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of artwork and baskets of fruit.

buildings.name: Pinhey's Point Historic Site
buildings.description: Pinhey’s Point Historic Site stands as a testament to upper and middle class rural life in the 19th century. Built in four stages from 1820 to 1849, the Georgian-style house maintains many of its original features, including the imposing entrance and staircase, servants’ quarters, and 1860s wallpaper. Explore the history of transportation in Ottawa from Steamships to Railways in our new exhibition, City in Motion.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a Georgian-style house built between 1820 and 1849.

buildings.name: Protection of the Holy Virgin Russian Orthodox Church
buildings.description: The Protection of the Holy Virgin Church was built to commemorate the 1,000-year anniversary of the baptism of Russia. Built according to the traditions of Russian Church architecture, it features golden onion domes, a five-tiered icon screen, and many hand-painted icons.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view featuring traditions of Russian Church architecture, including five golden onion domes.

buildings.name: Public Service Alliance of Canada
buildings.description: The Public Service Alliance of Canada HQ is a departure from a traditional square office building of reflecting glass. Ottawa architects Schoeler & Heaton’s 1968 design is a less imposing curved tower of brown-purple brick with inset windows. The Architectural Institution of Canada named it one of Canada’s top 500 millenniums buildings.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the 1968 award-winning multi-storey building featuring a curved tower of brown-purple brick with inset windows

buildings.name: Rideau Hall
buildings.description: Rideau Hall, with its buildings and beautiful grounds, is a national historic site and has been the official residence of the Governor General since 1867. It has been a stage for Canadian history for nearly 200 years. Visit the staterooms and learn about the history and role of the Governor General.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the national historic site, built in stages beginning in 1838. Featuring elaborate stone carvings above the entrance to the hall.

buildings.name: Rideau Valley Wildlife Sanctuary
buildings.description: The Rideau Valley Wildlife Sanctuary, a registered charity, is a wildlife rehabilitation centre in the Ottawa area that treats injured and orphaned wild mammals and reptiles. Approximately 1,500 animals are admitted each year. Visitors will receive a tour of the centre and see wildlife being fed and treated behind one-way viewing windows. There will also be several display booths and outdoor activities.
buildings.imageDescription: Photo of a wildlife caretaker with a baby porcupine.

buildings.name: Rogers tv
buildings.description: Rogers tv and tv Rogers invite you to stop by on Saturday, June 2, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Come visit our studios and discover the fascinating world of television, volunteer programming, program proposals, etc. This is an event not to be missed!
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the multi-level Rogers TV broadcasting station.

buildings.name: Royal Canadian Mint
buildings.description: Headquartered in the historic building where it was founded in 1908, this facility produces hand-crafted commemorative coins, gold and silver bullion, medals and medallions. A tour of the operations explains the many different coin manufacturing technologies. For an unforgettable souvenir, hold a 24 kt pure gold bar worth over $700,000. Guided tours 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone building built in 1908. Resembling a castle, if features two small turrets on each of the main entrance.

buildings.name: Saint-François d'Assise Church
buildings.description: (Sunday mass is at 11 a.m.)  For more than 125 years, the parish has been at the heart of Hintonburg. The church is renowned for its antique statues, its organ and its bells that ring twice daily. There is also a museum set up highlighting the history of the church and its place in the community.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a century-old stone church built in Gothic style with Romanesque features.

buildings.name: Scouts Canada National Museum
buildings.description: Visit the Scouts Canada National Museum to view impressive collections focusing on contributions Scouting has made to Canada’s heritage, while helping develop youth into valued Canadian citizens. See new-and-improved displays, including the reactivated Amateur Radio Station (VE3SHQ) that will be on-air June 2 and 3, contacting Amateur Radio Stations across North America. Come join the fun.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the Scouts Canada National Headquarters building which houses the national museum, and featuring a carved totem pole.

buildings.name: Shopify
buildings.description: Shopify is the leading cloud-based, multi-channel commerce platform. Our Ottawa office is our HQ and largest office but we are also located in Montreal, Toronto, Waterloo, San Francisco, Lithuania and Berlin. The offices are all designed as open flow with a different theme on each floor. The office offers a variety of workspaces to accommodate all personalities and working styles. Pre-registration required at www.eventbrite.ca/e/doors-open-ottawa-shopify-tickets-44335867774.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the glass Shopify building and a church steeple.

buildings.name: Smith & Barber - Stone Carving Studio
buildings.description: Visit the 800-square-foot sculpting studio used for drawing, clay modelling and plaster casting. The casts are used as reference pieces by sculptors who work in stone. The studio is equipped with carving stations for employees and students enrolled in carving classes. Most stoneworks are for larger projects, such as the restoration of West Block on Parliament Hill.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of stone carvings including masks and animals.

buildings.name: South Nepean Muslim Community
buildings.description: Built in the Barrhaven area between 2011 and 2014, the building has a unique architectural style that incorporates East and West fitting nicely within the Canadian Context. The centre caters to one of the most diverse Canadian Muslim communities – a multicultural community within the larger multicultural Canadian society. Visitors will need to remove their shoes in some areas.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a four-year-old building with a unique architectural style that incorporates East and West.

buildings.name: Southminster United Church
buildings.description: Designed by Ottawa architect J. Albert Ewart in the English Gothic Revival style, this landmark heritage building (1931) overlooks the Rideau Canal. The walls are Nepean sandstone and the roof is slate. The interior sanctuary has a high vaulted, wood panelled ceiling and a Casavant organ.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of an English Gothic Revival style church built in 1931.

buildings.name: Sri Sathya Sai Baba Spiritual Centre of Ottawa Carleton
buildings.address: 1694 Hunt Club Rd. (Entrance from Sable Ridge Dr.)
buildings.description: The spiritual centre is a unique, non-denominational place of worship. Sathya Sai Baba’s life message is to "love all, serve all" and "help ever, hurt never", strongly promoting the Unity of Faiths as depicted through symbols and messages on the centre’s pillar. Designed by M. David Blakely, the 19,000 sq ft building was completed in 1997.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a 19,000 square foot red brick non-denominational religious facility.

buildings.name: St. Albans Church
buildings.description: Designed by Thomas Fuller, architect of the Houses of Parliament, St. Albans is one of the oldest church buildings in Ottawa. A recent renovation received an Award of Merit for heritage restoration from the City and provides space for parish activities, theatrical and concert events, and Centre 454, a community ministry. Lara Legault photo.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the stone church, built in 1867, by Thomas Fuller.

buildings.name: St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church
buildings.description: (Sunday church service at 9:15 & 11 a.m.) In 1828, Thomas McKay built Bytown’s first stone church on this site, purchased from Nicholas Sparks. In 1873, a larger church was needed so architect W.T. Thomas built this impressive Gothic Revival structure with a distinctive Reformation arrangement of pews around a high central pulpit. Beautiful, vaulted ceiling and lovely stained glass.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone church built by W.T. Thomas in Gothic Revival style.

buildings.name: St. James Anglican Church Leitrim
buildings.description: Built in 1860, it is a good example of a rural Anglican church. It features an 1870s Horwood stained glass window, originally installed in Trinity church, Ottawa South. There will be a Blessing of the Animals on Sunday at 10:30 a.m. The public is welcome to bring their pets for this event. The Gloucester Historical Society and museum artefacts will also be open next door.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a white modest church building of frame construction, built in 1860.

buildings.name: St. John the Baptist Ukrainian Catholic Shrine
buildings.description: St. John the Baptist Ukrainian Catholic Shrine is in the 18th century Ukrainian baroque style - a synthesis of European baroque and cruciform Byzantine-Ukrainian styles. It is designated a Shrine because it represents the Canadian Ukrainian Catholic community in the nation’s capital. The Shrine is decorated with icons in the Byzantine style.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a Catholic Shrine built in 18th century Ukrainian baroque style, featuring multiple gold domes.

buildings.name: St. Mark the Evangelist Anglican Church
buildings.description: St. Mark’s was built in 1954 by renowned architect James W. Strutt. The church hall was built in 1966. The church has unique construction of nine A-frames of British-Columbian fir with a large sloping cedar roof. One end wall is filled by glass windows, while the other at the Sanctuary end is entirely made of cedar. The roof has a large solar panel cross that generates power for the church.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior photo of a modern A-framed church with solar panels on the roof that incorporates a giant cross into the design.

buildings.name: St. Mary's Anglican Church
buildings.description: New St. Mary’s was built in 1909 after the Old St Mary’s at Pinhey’s Point, built in 1827, was deemed  structurally unsafe. Many of the pews and other interior fixtures are from the Old St. Mary’s Church. Old St. Mary’s was the first Anglican church in the Ottawa Diocese and is the oldest church in the Ottawa area. Ten stained glass windows.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone church built in 1909.

buildings.name: St. Paul's Eastern United Church
buildings.description: St. Paul’s-Eastern United Church is one of the oldest congregations in Ottawa. The Romanesque Revival church was built from 1888 to 1889 for St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church by S.R. Badgley, architect. It originally had a large steeple. Unfortunately the church was built on sand and the steeple had to be removed, leaving a more squat building.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a church built in Romanesque Revival style between 1888 and 1889.

buildings.name: St. Peter's Lutheran Church
buildings.description: Erected in 1952, and built of sandstone from Nepean. Space designed by Cecil Burgess in the English Gothic Style. A Bell Carillon was installed in 2017, three swinging bells were installed in the tower in 2018, and the Casavant Organ was dedicated in 1977. Stained glass windows throughout are the work of Russell Goodman & Sons, installed between 1985 and 1993. Landscaping renovation was completed in 2010 for the 100th anniversary.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a church built of sandstone from Nepean in 1952.

buildings.name: Stadacona Hall - Brunei High Commission
buildings.description: The two-and-a-half-storey Gothic Revival style limestone home was built in 1871 for lumber magnate John A. Cameron, who first rented the property to Joseph-Édouard Cauchon, a cabinet minister and first speaker of the Senate. In 1882, Sir John A. and Lady MacDonald lived there before moving to Earnscliffe. It has also been home to the ambassadors of France and Belgium, and since 1996 it has been the High Commission of Brunei Darussalam.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a two and a half storey Gothic Revival style limestone home with white trim built in 1871.

buildings.name: Standard Bread Company/Gladstone Clayworks Co-op Pottery Studio
buildings.description: Built in 1924, the ground floor (east side) was converted into a pottery studio in 2003. The 1,800 sq ft co-operative studio now accommodates 25 ceramic artists who work together, sharing their experience and skill. The public will view artists at work, and a variety of finished artwork in the adjoining gallery.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the front entrance of the pottery studio.

buildings.name: Standards Building
buildings.description: The Standards Building is home to Measurement Canada, the federal agency responsible for ensuring trade measurement accuracy in Canada. The building houses the laboratories that test and certify gas pumps, retail scales, and electricity and natural gas meters for use in the marketplace. Tours of the laboratories and information on how measurement accuracy is assured will be provided.
buildings.imageDescription: Photo of measuring equipment used by the Government of Canada to ensure standardization.

buildings.name: Supreme Court of Canada
buildings.description: (1939) The Court’s distinguished presence is emphasized by its massive scale and commanding Grand Entrance Hall. Architect Ernest Cormier’s Art Deco design enhances the natural beauty of the exquisite woods and marble interior. After delays during WWII, the Court took possession of the building in 1946. Only the Grand Entrance and courtroom will be open. Photography restrictions.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the Supreme Court of Canada, built in Art Deco design in 1939.

buildings.name: TD Place
buildings.description: TD Place at Lansdowne is Ottawa’s exciting urban sports and entertainment destination that features a 24,000-seat outdoor stadium and a 10,000-seat indoor arena. It is home to the CFL’s Ottawa REDBLACKS, the USL’s Ottawa Fury FC, and the OHL’s Ottawa 67’s. It has also played host to many including the Grey Cup, FIFA, and AC/DC. Visit the Ottawa 67’s locker room for a peak behind the scenes!
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of the Ottawa 67's ice surface and stands filled with spectators.

buildings.name: The Delegation of the Ismaili Imamat
buildings.description: Designed by Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, this award-winning building serves a representational role for the Ismaili Imamat, reflecting the wide-ranging humanistic and humanitarian agenda of the Aga Khan Development Network and its associated institutions. Visitors can also see an exhibit on Canada’s role in supporting global development.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the award-winning building designed by Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, built in 2005.

buildings.name: The Ottawa Hospital Rehabilitation Centre
buildings.description: The Ottawa Hospital Rehabilitation Centre offers treatment programs and services including the virtual reality lab which simulates real life experience in a safe environment for therapy and research. The centre also houses the hospital’s state-of-the-art 3D printing program which creates prosthetics and 3D models for surgical treatment and research. Please pre-register at http://www.ottawahospital.on.ca/en/about-us/doors-open-ottawa/.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior view of a large wall to ceiling digital screen and a treadmill.

buildings.name: The Ottawa Mission
buildings.description: The Ottawa Mission (formerly the Union Mission for Men) was established in 1906 to help men experiencing homelessness. It has been at its current heritage location at the busy corner of Waller and Daly Avenue since 1912. It currently has 236 shelter beds, serves an average of 1,308 meals every day, and also provides programs such as addiction treatment, job training and a hospice.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the Ottawa Mission building, that shows three unique buildings now connected as one.

buildings.name: The Ottawa Regional Cancer Foundation's Maplesoft Centre
buildings.description: Open since 2011, The Cancer Foundation’s Maplesoft Centre is the first of its kind in Canada. The warm and welcoming building creates a calm and relaxing environment. The 11,463 square foot facility boasts unique elements including retractable walls, a water feature, theatre, and beautiful photography. During the Doors Open weekend, Take a Stand against cancer during Lemonade Standemonium! For more info visit http://ottawacancer.ca/lemonade.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a two-storey, 11,463 square foot facility built in 2011.

buildings.name: The Ottawa Rotary Home
buildings.description: The Ottawa Rotary Home is a respite home located on five acres of gardens and playgrounds. This state-of-the-art facility is fully accessible and features an open concept living space. Well-equipped bathrooms and bedrooms offer mechanical lifts and large hallways that allow the individuals we support to move freely in their home away from home.
buildings.imageDescription: Aerial view of the Ottawa Rotary Home and the green grounds that surround it.

buildings.name: The Ottawa Wedding Chapel
buildings.description: This chapel, built in 1907, has been completely refurbished and offers spectacular stained glass windows, beautiful wood, air-conditioning and unique curved pews. The chapel is also categorized as a heritage building, with amazing acoustics, an elegant aesthetic and a beautiful backyard. The chapel is non-denominational and open to all faiths and cultures.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of rows of wooden pews, several stained glass windows, and beautifully maintained hardwood floors.

buildings.name: The Royal Canadian Geographical Society (RCGS)
buildings.description: 50 Sussex, Canada’s new Centre for Geography and Exploration, is home of The Royal Canadian Geographical Society. The RCGS is active in supporting cutting edge geographical research, funds amazing expeditions, and supports over 20,000 educators nationwide through the Canadian Geographic Education program. The building is a state of the art facility, which will serve the capital region for years to come.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a modern grey building with a green tinted double-storey glass entrance.

buildings.name: The University of Ottawa Skills and Simulation Centre
buildings.description: The University of Ottawa Skills and Simulation Centre houses four state-of-the-art simulation rooms including two operating rooms, one intensive care room, and a labour and delivery suite/emergency room. Computer driven mannequins that can breathe, talk, bleed, and respond to medication help recreate patient care within the hospital, providing professionals with hands-on training and experience. Please pre-register at http://www.ottawahospital.on.ca/en/about-us/doors-open-ottawa/.
buildings.imageDescription: Interior photo of three doctors operating on a mannequin as part of a simulation.

buildings.name: Thomson Hall o/a The Keg Manor
buildings.description: A Georgian style estate, Thomson Hall was built between 1831 and 1833 by William Thomson. A private residence until 1989, it has been occupied by The Keg Manor since 1999. To the east of the house, a walled garden dating back to 1833 served as a vegetable garden for the families who lived there.  It is now open to the public and cared for by the Friends of Maplelawn.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a stone Georgian-style estate built between 1831 and 1833.

buildings.name: Vanier Museopark
buildings.description: The Vanier Museopark was named because of its location in the Richelieu Park. The property called Richelieu Park belonged to the Society of Missionaries of Africa. They built an important seminary on the site in 1938. They also exploited the sugar bush nearby, which made way for the sugar shack to be built in 1998.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a red-brick community centre that is home to the Vanier Museopark.

buildings.name: VCA Canada - Alta Vista Animal Hospital
buildings.description: Established in 1958, VCA Canada Alta Vista Animal Hospital functions just like a human hospital. With a staff of 160 people, including 35 veterinarians, the hospital offers 24-hour emergency care, general care, an intensive care unit for our critical patients, and a referral centre including CT, MRI and the first hyperbaric oxygen chamber for pets in Canada. Kids, bring your stuffed animals for the popular teddy bear surgery.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of the single-storey animal hospital.

buildings.name: Vietnam House
buildings.description: Built in 1913, the house is a low, sprawling structure and was Noffke’s first design in what was to become the architect’s favorite idiom of Spanish-Colonial Revival.  The house has been designated of heritage value by the City of Ottawa.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of a 1913 home built in a low, sprawling structure of Spanish-Colonial Revival style.

buildings.name: Wabano Centre for Aboriginal Health
buildings.description: The Wabano Centre for Aboriginal Health is an award-winning and internationally-recognized healthcare facility, leading the way in community based care and cultural programming. Filled with natural light, grand ceilings, Aboriginal art and awe-inspiring architecture by Douglas Cardinal, Wabano has become a place of belonging for all who visit. It is also home to the Wabano Meeting and Events Centre.
buildings.imageDescription: Exterior view of an award-winning and internationally recognized healthcare centre designed by Douglas Cardinal.

buildings.name: Wallis House
buildings.description: Wallis House is a designated Heritage building originally built as the Carleton County Protestant General Hospital in 1873.
